Jokes aside, funny you should mention distilled water. Distilled water can also reach a supercooled state, another way to get ice spikes. When something disturbs supercooled water, it freezes quickly. When this happens, whatever shape it takes when that portion of supercooled water is frozen, is held by the ice. The water could then show minor ice spikes from just the disturbance, or the existing shape as it freezes could get extruded, creating these.
Not to say that this is happening very often when you observe ice spikes, just that it can contribute to the probability.

More importantly, why do ice cubes explode in your drinks? It happens when you are impatient and disturb the ice cube tray before all cubes are frozen, thus introducing air bubbles that explode once they are warmed up (expanded) in a liquid. Ice spikes are likely due to opening the freezer too many times before the cubes freeze. Thus causing them to freeze slower. I'm not sure about the latter, but I am positive about the cause of the prior. No more stains on my ceilings from exploding ice cubes.

Rivers can freeze from the bottom up.  The Scots have a name for the slushy ice that forms on the bed it's called "grue".  It forms when the water is a bit turbulent and becomes supercooled in below 0 Celsius.  It remains unfrozen because the turbulence prevents freezing.  But very close to the bed the flow becomes very slow through friction with the bed and water freezes onto the pebbles on the bed because there is very little turbulence.  I have  seen it on one or two occasions in the burns of the Scottish Highlands.

Well, if water didn't expand when it froze, it wouldn't really be water.  Water is pretty integral to life on Earth to start with, and the reason for that (apart from say, combustion which is more about energies and electrons, but still pretty crucial to life) is because of water's polar nature, which makes it such a good solvent, which causes it to expand when it freezes, which causes it to not leak out of our cells, and a bunch of other things. 

I mean, water has to expand when it freezes as a byproduct of all of the other things that it ends up being good for.  If water didn't expand when it froze, then yeah, many of those things, like the ocean not freezing, might not happen, but then again, whatever life forms that existed in the universe wouldn't really care about that, because water, at least in the way we expect it to exist, wouldn't be that important to their wellbeing.

Whatever the case, I'm glad it's not wizards that are making the ice spikes.
